def solve(s):
    if s == s[::-1]:
        return True
    else:
        for i in range(len(s)):
            temp = list(s)
            for j in range(26):
                temp[i] = chr(ord('a') + j)
                if temp == temp[::-1]:
                    return True
    return False

def solve(s):
    if s == s[::-1]:  # if string is already a palindrome
        return False  # it is not possible to convert it by changing one character
    
    n = len(s)
    for i in range(n):  # iterate through each character in the string
        s_new = s[:i] + s[i+1:]  # remove the ith character from the string
        if s_new == s_new[::-1]:  # if the new string is a palindrome
            return True  # it is possible to convert the original string by changing one character
    
    return False  # it is not possible to convert the original string by changing one character

def solve(s):
    if s == s[::-1]:  # Check if the string is already a palindrome
        return False  # If it is, it is not possible to convert it to a palindrome by changing one character

    for i in range(len(s)):
        modified_s = s[:i] + s[i+1:]  # Remove the current character from the string
        if modified_s == modified_s[::-1]:  # Check if the modified string is a palindrome
            return True  # If it is, it is possible to convert the original string to a palindrome by changing one character

    return False  # If no possible conversion is found, return False

def solve(s):
    # initialize the count of different characters to 0
    diff_count = 0
    
    # iterate through the string
    for i in range(len(s)//2):
        # if the characters at the two ends are different
        if s[i] != s[len(s)-i-1]:
            # increment the count
            diff_count += 1
    
    # if the count of different characters is at most 1, return True
    # otherwise, return False
    return diff_count <= 1

def solve(s):
    if s == s[::-1]:  # If the string is already a palindrome, return False
        return False
    for i in range(len(s)):
        s_copy = s[:i] + s[i+1:]  # Remove the i-th character from the string
        if s_copy == s_copy[::-1]:  # If the modified string is a palindrome, return True
            return True
    return False  # If no palindrome can be obtained by changing one character, return False

def solve(s):
    # initialize a counter for the number of characters that need to be changed
    count = 0
    
    # loop through the string up to the middle character
    for i in range(len(s) // 2):
        # check if the character at index i is not equal to the character at the corresponding index from the end of the string
        if s[i] != s[len(s) - 1 - i]:
            # if they are not equal, increment the counter
            count += 1
            
            # if the counter exceeds 1, return False
            if count > 1:
                return False
                
    # if the counter is 1 or less, return True
    return count <= 1

def solve(s):
    # Convert the string to a list for easier manipulation
    s_list = list(s)
    
    # Check if the string is already a palindrome
    if s_list == s_list[::-1]:
        return True
    
    # Iterate through each character in the string
    for i in range(len(s_list)):
        # Copy the original character
        original = s_list[i]
        
        # Try changing the character to every other possible character
        for j in range(26):
            # Get the ASCII value of the character to change to
            new = chr(ord('a') + j)
            
            # Change the character in the list
            s_list[i] = new
            
            # Check if the modified string is a palindrome
            if s_list == s_list[::-1]:
                return True
            
            # Change the character back to the original
            s_list[i] = original
    
    # If no palindrome can be created, return False
    return False

def solve(s):
    # Get the length of the string
    n = len(s)
    
    # Initialize a counter for the number of differences
    differences = 0
    
    # Loop through the string from both ends
    for i in range(n // 2):
        # Check if the characters are different
        if s[i] != s[n - i - 1]:
            # Increment the counter
            differences += 1
            
            # If there are more than 1 differences, return False
            if differences > 1:
                return False
    
    # If there is exactly 1 difference or none, return True
    return differences <= 1

def solve(s):
    """
    Check if it is possible to convert a string to a palindrome by changing one character.
    
    Args:
    s (str): The input string to check.
    
    Returns:
    bool: True if it is possible to convert the string to a palindrome by changing one character, False otherwise.
    """
    
    # Check if the string is already a palindrome
    if s == s[::-1]:
        return False
    
    # Check if we can change one character to make the string a palindrome
    for i in range(len(s)):
        # Try changing each character to all possible characters
        for c in [chr(ord('a')+j) for j in range(26)]:
            if s[i] != c:
                # If changing the character at position i to c makes the string a palindrome, return True
                if s[:i] + c + s[i+1:] == (s[:i] + c + s[i+1:])[::-1]:
                    return True
    
    # If we cannot change one character to make the string a palindrome, return False
    return False

def solve(s):
    if s == s[::-1]: # check if the string is already a palindrome
        return False # if it is, return False because we cannot change any character to make it a palindrome
    
    n = len(s)
    
    for i in range(n):
        if s[i] != s[n - i - 1]: # check if the characters at the i-th position from the front and back are different
            new_s = s[:i] + s[n - i - 1] + s[i+1:] # create a new string by replacing the character at the i-th position from the front with the character at the i-th position from the back
            if new_s == new_s[::-1]: # check if the new string is a palindrome
                return True # if it is, return True because we can change the character to make it a palindrome
    
    return False # if we have checked all positions and haven't found a solution, return False

def solve(s):
    # Convert string to list for easier modification
    s = list(s)
    # Get the length of the string
    n = len(s)
    
    # Initialize a counter for the number of changes needed
    changes = 0
    
    # Loop through the first half of the string
    for i in range(n//2):
        # Compare the characters at the start and end of the string
        if s[i] != s[n-i-1]:
            # If the characters are different, increment the changes counter
            changes += 1
            
            # Replace one of the characters with the other character
            if s[i] > s[n-i-1]:
                s[i] = s[n-i-1]
            else:
                s[n-i-1] = s[i]
                
            # Check if the string is now a palindrome
            if s == s[::-1]:
                return True
            
            # If the string is not a palindrome, return False
            else:
                return False
    
    # If all characters are the same, return False
    return False

def solve(s):
    # If the string is already a palindrome, return False
    if s == s[::-1]:
        return False
    
    # Count the number of characters that are not equal to their mirror image
    count = sum([1 for i in range(len(s) // 2) if s[i] != s[-(i+1)]])
    
    # If there is only one character that is not equal to its mirror image, return True
    return count == 1

def solve(s):
    count = 0
    for i in range(len(s)//2):
        if s[i] != s[-i-1]:
            count += 1
        if count > 1:
            return False
    return True

        return False

    for i in range(len(s)):  # Iterate through each character in the string
        new_s = s[:i] + s[i+1:]  # Remove the current character

        if new_s == new_s[::-1]:  # Check if the new string is a palindrome
            return True

    return False

def solve(s):
    if s == s[::-1]: # check if s is already a palindrome
        return True

    count = 0
    for i in range(len(s)//2):
        if s[i] != s[-i-1]: # check if characters at symmetric positions are different
            count += 1
            if count > 1: # if more than one character needs to be changed, it's not possible to convert to a palindrome
                return False

    return True

def solve(s):
    # Initialize the count of different characters
    count = 0
    
    # Check if the string is a palindrome
    is_palindrome = s == s[::-1]
    
    # If the string is a palindrome, return True
    if is_palindrome:
        return True
    
    # If the string is not a palindrome, count the number of different characters
    for i in range(len(s)//2):
        if s[i] != s[-i-1]:
            count += 1
    
    # If there is only one different character, return True
    if count == 1:
        return True
    
    # Otherwise, return False
    return False

def solve(s):
    # Variable to store the number of mismatches
    count = 0
    
    # Loop through the string
    for i in range(len(s)//2):
        # If the characters don't match
        if s[i] != s[-(i+1)]:
            # Increment the count of mismatches
            count += 1
    
    # Return True if there is only one mismatch, False otherwise
    return count == 1

def solve(s):
    # Convert the string to a list for easy modification
    s = list(s)
    
    # Initialize a count of the number of characters that need to be changed
    count = 0
    
    # Loop through half of the string
    for i in range(len(s) // 2):
        # Compare the characters on opposite sides of the string
        if s[i] != s[-i - 1]:
            # If they are different, increment the count
            count += 1
            # Set the character on the left side to the character on the right side
            s[i] = s[-i - 1]
    
    # If the count is greater than 1, it is not possible to convert the string to a palindrome by changing one character
    if count > 1:
        return False
    
    return True

def solve(s):
    # Convert string to list for easier modification
    s = list(s)
    # Get the length of the string
    n = len(s)
    
    # Initialize a counter for the number of changes needed
    changes = 0

    for i in range(n//2):
        # Compare the characters at the start and end of the string

            changes += 1
            
            # Replace one of the characters with the other character
            if s[i] > s[n-i-1]:
                s[i] = s[n-i-1]
            else:
                s[n-i-1] = s[i]
                
            # Check if the string is now a palindrome

def solve(s):
    # If the string is already a palindrome, return False
    if s == s[::-1]:
        return False
    
    # Count the number of characters that are not equal to their mirror image
    count = sum([1 for i in range(len(s) // 2) if s[i] != s[-(i+1)]])
    
    # If there is only one character that is not equal to its mirror image, return True
    return count == 1
